Award.AwardTitle: NSF CREST Center for Nano & Bio-Inspired Materials and Devices (CNBMD)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A scientific team from Norfolk State University (NSU) will initiate a Center for Nano- and Bio-Inspired Materials and Devices (CNBMD) to perform cutting edge research for a range of relevant high-impact applications in medicine, environment, and renewable energy. The research outcomes of this Center will have a tremendous impact on diagnosis and treatments; enabling transformation in health and environmental diagnostics, with for example neural disorders, including Alzheimer?s disease.

The research direction of this Center will focus on fast-moving development in nanotechnologies with strong insight into both fundamental and applied aspects of nanoscience. CNBMD will bring together, engineers, physicists, chemists, materials scientists and biologists from universities, industry, and national laboratories to a single multidisciplinary platform, not only to explore both fundamental and applied aspects of nano-materials; but also, to implement education, outreach and mentoring initiatives.

The knowledge gained within the Center?s research programs will be transferred to a broad community of scientists, engineers, educators, and students and will enrich key technologies. During its five-year span, the CNBMD will provide education and hands-on training in Nano- and Bio-technology, infrastructure support to a larger research community, and will establish links between NSU and other institutions. The synergistic research and education activities of the multidisciplinary CNBMD will profoundly impact students belonging to minority groups in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). CNBMD will provide the impetus for the expansion of an overarching infrastructure to foster and support interdisciplinary scholarship, an institutional priority, as NSU positions itself to increase its capacity to prepare a diverse population to become leaders in the global scientific and engineering community.

Intellectual Merit
The proposed multi-scale effort will feature 1) Transformative research on the properties of new generations of engineered nano-materials, 2) Development of materials that will enable a new class of devices and ultimately new technologies, and 3) Development of a range of education programs based on the findings of cutting edge research. The project introduces a new collaboration with the NSU Center for Biotechnology and Biomedical Science, which will be of benefit to both groups.

Broader Impact
The development and implementation of nanotechnology for biomedical, energy and environmental sensing applications have tremendous societal impact. Nanotechnology has the potential to dramatically improve the effectiveness of a number of existing consumer and industrial products and could have a substantial impact on the development of new products ranging from disease diagnosis and treatment to environmental remediation. The knowledge gained within the Center?s research programs will be transferred to a broad community of scientists, engineers, educators, and students and will enrich key technologies. The education and training of a diverse and new generation of scientists, in the areas of nanomaterials and devices, will replace retiring researchers in academia and research laboratories. During its five-year span, the CNBMD will provide education and hands-on training in Nano- and Bio-technology, infrastructure support to a larger research community, and will establish links between NSU and other institutions. The synergistic research and education activities of the multidisciplinary CNBMD will profoundly impact students belonging to minority groups in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). CNBMD will provide the impetus for the expansion of an overarching infrastructure to foster and support interdisciplinary scholarship, an institutional priority, as NSU positions itself to increase its capacity to prepare a diverse population to become leaders in the global scientific and engineering community.

ProgramElement.Text: Centers for Rsch Excell in S&T

ProgramReference.Text: CENTERS FOR RSCH EXCELL IN S&T

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF CREST Center for Nano and Bio Inspired Materials and Devices (CNBMD) innovative research tasks focused on three areas: 1) nanostructured materials, aligned nanostructures, nanoelectrodes, and core-shell nanostructures; 2) bio-inspired materials including aspects of self- assembly and cytotoxity; and 3) bio- and environmental- sensing.

The outcomes of this research include aligned nanostructured materials, nano- electrodes and core-shell nanostructures leading to the fabrication of structures and devices used in sensor applications, as bio-markers, for protein purification, for drug delivery, for magnetic resonance imagining (MRI), and for contrast hyperthermia. A full suite of toxicity tests of the synthesized nanostructures was carried out to determine biocompatibility.

A highly sensitive, biosensing platform, comprised of microwave synthesized CdSe­ZnO core­shell nanostructure, for targeted applications in protein detection was demonstrated. This innovative technique uses a microwave­ assisted thermal decomposition method allowing a rapid, less hazardous, and user-friendly procedure to synthesize core­shell structures.

Extensive research on the unique properties of aluminum-doped zinc oxide Al:ZnO (AZO) led to the creation of  a memristor device based on AZO thin films having metallic, semiconducting, and insulating transport properties. A high-performance AZO­based transparent heater, synthesized by the ALD technique, was created and it is expected to find uses in a broad range of applications, including smart electronics/sensors, automobile defogging/deicing systems and smart windows. Using electron beam lithography (EBL), AZO was nanopatterned for plasmonic waveguide applications, to selectively grow aligned nanorods for environmental sensing, and for Li-ion power storage cells. A widely tunable AZO multilayer structure was fabricated and investigated for metamaterials applications, such as near­to­mid­infrared sensing, plasmonic wave guides and communication.

Fe3O4 nanoparticles and different grades of magnetic cobalt ferrite (CoFe2O4) nanoparticles were synthesized and characterized. The magnetic studies demonstrated that all of the nanoparticles are superparamagnetic at 300K. Various experiments were conducted, both invitro and invivo, using a mice model to check the toxicity of the synthesized zinc oxide nanorods, Fe3O4, CoFe2O4 and their core-shell nanoparticles. The results showed that the synthesized ZnO nanorods had no significant dose- or time-dependent increase in the formation of free radicals, or loss of cell viability on lung epithelial cell lines. In addition, it was found that the uncoated Fe3O4 and CoFe2O4 nanoparticles induce significant amount of oxidative stress and decrease cell viability on lung epithelial cells, as compared to silica coated cobalt iron nanoparticles. Conversely, with higher concentration of gold and silane coated CoFe2O4 nanoparticles as well as Fe3O4 nanoparticles showed remarkable reduction in oxidative stress and cell death. The attained coating protocol of the magnetic nanoparticles with the polymer as well as the achieved stability will promote the use of these magnetic nanoparticles in drug release applications and biomedicine.

 

Controlled self­assembly of DNA nanostructures was achieved on electron beam lithographically (EBL) patterned surfaces at lower energy and the periodicity in DNA self­assembly was observed.  In addition, a general approach for the fabrication of the biosensors using EBL technique was demonstrated showing a promise for multiscale DNA sensing opportunities.

 

Neural probes, with aligned nanowire electrodes, were fabricated on a flexible polymer substrate and a microdrive was fabricated and tested. Wireless data acquisition and communication for invivo and real-time monitoring of neural signals, from a freely moving rat, were analyzed. The development of microelectrodes for neural recording devices is important to better understand the brain and how it communicates with the body. 

A novel method, to construct three-dimensional nanostructure stacking with dielectric thin films grown by ALD, was developed to study surface enhanced Raman scattering (SERS). Several novel nanostructures were artificially prepared by the EBL technique and their plasmonic response was measured and demonstrated for bio­sensor applications.

A glucose sensor with linear range of 0.1 mM­10.6 mM was developed and designed.  The electrode provided a sensitivity of 18.15μAcm­1mM­1 and a limit of detection of 0.1 mM. This sensor is promising in the studies on prostate specific antigen (PSA) antibody.

The broader impacts of the CREST CNBMD fell into three categories: science, education/training, and diversity. The knowledge gained within the Center’s research programs can be transferred to a broad community of scientists, engineers, and educators, and will enrich key technologies. The interdisciplinary nature of this research increased synergy and promoted collaboration across disciplines. By developing various nanomaterials, prototype devices, and protocols the CREST CNBMD pushed the limits and frontiers of research in the areas of health, environmental monitoring, energy, biomedicine, drug delivery, biotoxicity, and neuroscience. In addition, students were taught to think critically about the cytotoxicity of new technologies and its impact on environment and society. The education and hands-on training in nano- and bio-technology provided by CREST CNBMD created a diverse and new generation of scientists, in the areas of nanomaterials and devices. These graduates will replenish retiring researchers in academia and research laboratories. The project impacted thousands of K­12 students through hand-on activities and targeted outreach STEM activities to minority and underrepresented communities.


Last Modified: 11/23/2017
Modified by: Messaoud Bahoura
